Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 07:15AM kerry_lamb wrote: Hey Wink! I have been working full time during my chemo, primarily for financial reasons. But there are other advantages as well. My workplace ( a prep - Yr 10 country school) is a love factory and is very supportive. It's important to be distracted and happy. I have chemo on a Friday so I can rest over the weekend. The steroids keep me awake for about 3 days, and its hard to go to work sleep-deprived so being quiet and still (though awake) is possible over a weekend.  Make sure you don't eat too much or eat food which taxes the digestive system (like big steaks) I have rolled rye for breakfast (cooked for 2 mins in the MW) which I have soaked in water overnight. I add 2 tablespoons of ground linseed and have it with low fat soy milk. I also eat some pumpernickle every day. This all keeps the colon active. Believe me, this is important. Eat plenty of silverbeet, fresh beetroot and salads. Your blood tests will be better for it. Drink masses of water because dehydration truly is your enemy and will keep you away from work. I went back to work two weeks after my mastectomy. I was vigilant about the physio exercises because you only have ONE recovery period, so make it count. You DO NOT want to have reduced arm/shoulder mobility. Remember..you are going to live a long and active life :)  You might want to reconsider having a double M. Remember you need  a good set of veins for future tests etc. And a double risk lymphedema? No way..not unless you really have to.  The fatigue was a shock. Everything you read about exercising is true. It's just that about 3 or 4 days after chemo you might be too tired to even think. When you are not too tired, walk miles. Make this a priority because it will make you feel better and keep you going to work. Always have some antacid tablets with you and eat them. They are a mini miracle. Most importantly, go to bed early..7pm is not too early! Even if you can't sleep, it's incredibly important to let your body do as little as possible apart from kill those cancer cells!  Good luck with it, and don't be afraid. This is a big, fat adventure. You will be an iron maiden after this! Much love!

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 09:35PM kerry_lamb wrote: Hey Ness! It's so funny that you call me 'Little Lamb'. My REALLY tall students all call me that! You will be a bit sore, but I think you will be pleasantly surprised on that front. Take 1000 omega 3 fish oil caps. For some reason they gave me a great kick-along. Your recovery will also be surprisingly quick, especially if you follow the surgeons advice to the letter. This was hard for me... Don't be afraid of taking simple pain-killers so you can sleep. It's lack of sleep that will wear you down and do your head in. Cancer is a very private world and men can feel shut out because they, by gender, just want things fixed (and they can't fix them, in this case). I encouraged my beautiful husband to just be quietly very loving, and to spend time with his most supportive male friends. This has been great. Basically, we can't access their pain and fears, and they can't access ours. It should never become a competition..that can be very destructive. So mutual love, support and tenderness is absolutely the best thing.  I got the shock of my life when my lumpectomy proved positive, and because of the type of breast tissue I have, I had to go with the big 'M'. (I could not screen very well in the future). So be prepared for that suggestion, but don't freak out about it. It's easy to! But resist. One day at a time really is the go. XX

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 07:03PM kerry_lamb wrote: Hi Ness, You are sounding very brave for a young thang! Your daughter is 3? Don't talk to her about it..she has a very short attention span, and besides she's in that part of life where ignorance really is bliss! Re your daughter's risk: I read a very interesting article..maybe from a link on this site..about looking after breasts from the time they grow. Alcohol is OUT, as is smoking, as is obesity. The info was breast specific. Your daughter is the perfect age to establish all these health protocols, so she is actually really lucky to have you, who is now so aware. I agree with all the health pros, even Jamie Oliver (!) who insist that we stop feeding our kids so much shite. White meat and 3 veg, 3 fruit, fish from Alaska, eggs, some yoghurt & cheese and nothing but whole grains (bread and cereal) is pretty much it. Water, caught in a bucket from the sky. Food produced close to home. Get rid of as much packaged and artificially coloured & preserved stuff as you possible can. Our cancer journey did not begin when we were diagnosed. It started when we were tiny..for whatever reason, and what we put in our mouths HUGELY effects it. Teach you daughter to LOVE physical activity too. Get her out in the bush, or forest, I think you gals call it. Re mastectomy: take your surgeon's advice on that one. It came as a shock to me, but I had every faith in her. I'm glad I did it , even though in the end it was my choice. Good luck and stay strong. Do you have a man to take care of you? I will pray for you XX

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2008 08:17PM kerry_lamb wrote: Hey pinkylee, What these girls say is true. The unknown is just so hard..I had a single M, and it all happened in such a blur! But after the op, when it's all known and final, I was fine. I was really relieved to have the cancerous mass gone. There was a sudden shortage of beds in my private hospital..I knew an elderly man had travelled a long way had to sit in the waiting room ALL DAY because of hold-ups with beds. I offered to go home two days early because I was feeling so well. My surgeon concurred!  I am having a reduction and recon next May. Yours will be brilliant. Have you seen the pics on TimTams special photo pages yet? They will inspire you. Much love and prayers. kerry

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 02:34PM kerry_lamb wrote: Beesie I could probably have avoided a mastectomy if I didn't have really dense breast tissue. My cancer was found in a freakish stroke of fate. After the lumpectomy, the decision (made by 4 specialists) was unanimous: I would never be able to effectively screen for a recurrence because of the density. Perhaps in the past this has influenced the stats, and now more girls with very dense breasts are having a mastectomy.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 04:49PM kerry_lamb wrote: Cristl, that hair system is quite widely used, especially by African girls here in Australia who want really straight hair for a few months. (The wigs are not their own hair..but same deal with the glue etc). You can check it out on YouTube, from memory. But they have healthy scalps with growing hair underneath. I bought a wig, buzzed my mane, and just started wearing it as though it grew like that. I am a teacher and my wig is the OPPOSITE to my normal hair but the kids adjusted and still keep telling me how beautiful my hair is..which is a bit of a worry..my real hair will disappoint them when it grows back!   I found it essential all the way through chemo to slather the nivea cream on my skull, and to monitor the skin. The thing is, time flies believe it or not and once you lose your hair, you will be less stressed about it. I am more stressed trying to get something resembling eyebrows drawn on! I am grateful for my wig but NEVER wear it at home. Good luck! Tough it out. It ends!!!
